thread.title: Anne Arundel County faces extreme heat advisory and abnormally dry conditions

author: Bridget Byrne
title: Anne Arundel County faces extreme heat advisory and abnormally dry conditions
text:
Share this: Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window) By Bridget Byrne | bbyrne@baltsun.com UPDATED: August 1, 2024 at 5:29 p.m. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory for the D.C., Maryland, and Virginia area Thursday, and officials urged water conservation as a regional agency issued a drought watch for Anne Arundel County.
“Widespread, dangerous heat will unfortunately be the main weather story for much of the country this week as one heat wave continues,” the National Weather Service’s advisory said Thursday.
About 82% of Anne Arundel County is “abnormally dry” and nearly 18% is considered be in “moderate drought,” according to the National Integrated Drought Information System.
The Drought Coordination Committee of the Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments declared a drought watch on Monday. Currently, there is an adequate supply of water in the Potomac River and backup reservoirs, but following the regional drought response plan and implementing voluntary water conservation practices across the region will help complement measures already in place and reduce water demand.
A drought watch is the level in the drought respone plan before drought warning, when additional water restrictions are requested and could become mandatory should conditions worsen.
“As officials continue to closely monitor drought conditions in the region, it is important for the public to use water wisely,” said Clark Mercer, COG executive director, adding that “with a few simple measures, we can all aid in water conservation efforts and help ensure an adequate water supply for our region.”
Residents should monitor watering lawns, avoid washing cars, fix any plumbing leaks, reduce shower lengths, turn off water while brushing teeth and wash only full loads of dishes and clothes. While the region is currently at a low to moderate risk for wildfires, COG encourages residents to use extra caution when smoking outside, using outdoor grills or engaging in other activities that involve flammable materials.
Anne Arundel County has several county cooling centers for community members seeking relief from the heat. Senior activity centers and public libraries are available during business hours, and police department district station lobbies are available 24/7.
Annapolis set up a cooling center in the Roger “Pip” Moyer Community Recreation Center that will stay open through Saturday.
“We have seen the effects of extreme heat in other communities. Now that it is Annapolis’ turn, it is important to know the signs of heat-related illness,” Annapolis Mayor Gavin Buckley said in the news release announcing the cooling center. “If your neighbors are vulnerable, help them get to a cooling center before they are in crisis. It’s times like this when we need to look out for each other.”
Originally Published: August 1, 2024 at 5:29 p.m.
